subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: Oops, I do get confused with numbers....... I should have said, if it is stressed, then use #27. Another point I meant to comment on was the use of letter t
messageBody:
Oops, I do get confused with numbers....... I should have said, if it is stressed, then use #27.

Another point I meant to comment on was the use of letter "t" in the middle of words.  Personally, I will ALWAYS use "t" wherever it is spelled unless it is followed by a consonant.  But is is becoming
more and more common in England, especially in London, to drop the T altogether except at the begining of words (and even then in lazy speak).

Moira

On 15/11/2007, Moira O'Brien <moirajaneob@...> wrote:
I feel I must contribute to this debate in respect of terminal #27EAt or #26It.

Kingsley Read was specific in his directions - if the syllable is unstressed then use #26 - if it is stressed then use #26.  This accords with both my speach and most of the English and American  that I hear.

I really cannot understand anyone pronouncing say "family" as "familee" with the stress on the "ee".  So I am 100% behind KR's rule of #26 for unstressed terminal "ily" endings and the like.

regards

Moira


On 15/11/2007, Anthony Grahn < othermale@...> wrote:

Thanks a million for your review! I've applied the change you
suggested and uploaded a new chart.

>
> And one warning. Some Australians may want to keep terminal
> unstressed "Eat" written as #27Eat, rather than #26It.
> ...
> But some of those spellings are quite idiosyncratic and
> would, I think, make Australian QS too difficult to read elsewhere.)
> Keep your footnote as it is.
>

 I too am personally annoyed at using a terminal #26It for a sound that
to me is obviously "Eat". But Read's rule about this does solve a real
issue; namely to make QS more of a morphophonemic writing system. It
is the same reason there are rules for omitting vowels when tacking on
the letter Zoo for some plurals and Day for past tenses and Ing etc.
Maybe the QM rules are in error, thier purpose is certainly never
explained. And maybe in some of these cases the burden of non phonemic
writing is higher than the morphemic benefit. Personally though I want
to clearly analyze and describe these rules before abandoning them.

Once the long-over-due morphemic discussion starts I imagine we are
going to want more such rules rather than fewer.






--
Moira O'Brien
